title: What if the Earth stopped spinning?

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the Earth suddenly stopped spinning?

options.label: B
options.text: The atmosphere would expand and cause massive fires, unparalleled erosion, and damage to anything strong enough to stay put.

title: What happens when you remove the hippocampus? - Sam Kean

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: H.M.'s seizures remained the same, and his IQ stayed the same, with a change in personality.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: He wrote it down and kept it in a notebook.

options.label: C
options.text: He didn't remember it at all.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a special device to store it.

multiple-choice.question: According to Brenda Milner's findings, what is the difference between short-term and long-term memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Short-term memory is used for storing information temporarily, while long-term memory is used for storing information for a long time.

options.label: B
options.text: Short-term memory is used for storing information for a long time, while long-term memory is used for storing information temporarily.

options.label: C
options.text: Both short-term and long-term memory are used for storing information temporarily.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference between short-term and long-term memory.

options.label: A
options.text: He did perfectly on the first try.

options.label: B
options.text: He did horribly on the first try, but improved over repeated trials, even though he had no memory of previous attempts.

options.label: C
options.text: He forgot how to do it after a few tries.

multiple-choice.question: According to Brenda Milner's findings, what is the difference between declarative memory and procedural memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Declarative memory is used for storing information about facts and events, while procedural memory is used for storing information about skills and habits.

options.label: B
options.text: Declarative memory is used for storing information about skills and habits, while procedural memory is used for storing information about facts and events.

options.label: C
options.text: Both declarative and procedural memory are used for storing information about facts and events.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference between declarative and procedural memory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hippocampus in memory formation?

options.label: A
options.text: It is responsible for storing information temporarily.

options.label: B
options.text: It is responsible for storing information permanently.

options.label: C
options.text: It is responsible for strengthening cortical synaptic connections and transferring memories to the cortex for permanent storage.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not involved in memory formation.

multiple-choice.question: Why did H.M.'s brain become the most studied mind in history?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of his exceptional memory and cognitive abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of his unique brain structure and function.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the numerous examinations and studies conducted by neuroscientists.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of his famous case study and contributions to our understanding of memory, which have had a lasting impact on the field of neuroscience.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fundamental distinction that underpins all memory research and has significant implications for our understanding of memory.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a distinction that only applies to short-term memory.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a distinction that only applies to long-term memory.

multiple-choice.question: Why is H.M.'s legacy important for our understanding of memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of his exceptional memory and cognitive abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of his unique brain structure and function.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the numerous examinations and studies conducted by neuroscientists.

options.label: D

title: Feedback loops: How nature gets its rhythms - Anje-Margriet Neutel

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element that makes everything work in the grand orchestra of nature?

options.text: The increase in the hare population

options.label: C
options.text: The buildup of humus in the soil, providing moisture and nutrients for other plants to grow

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the ecosystem

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: They amplify changes in the ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: They counteract changes in the ecosystem, maintaining a stable balance

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on the ecosystem

title: What can Schrödinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the physics of everyday objects and the physics of atoms?

What is the phenomenon where a particle can be in multiple states at the same time, such as being in multiple places at once?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the particles can communicate with each other

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the phenomenon of entanglement

options.label: C
options.text: Because the particles are connected through a physical link

options.label: D
options.text: Because the particles are in a superposition state

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What was the devastating disease outbreak that occurred in the 14th century and is believed to have killed nearly 50% of Europeans in just four years?

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate percentage of the Earth's surface that coral reefs make up?
According to the transcript, what is one of the ways in which coral reef fish larvae navigate their environment?
In what is one of the ways in which the larvae of many fish species move vertically in the water column to increase their chances of survival?

options.label: A
options.text: They are swept away by ocean currents

options.label: B
options.text: They absorb oxygen directly from the water through their tissue-thin skin

options.label: C
options.text: They move vertically to place themselves in different water masses and ride certain currents

options.label: D
options.text: They don't move vertically at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of a fish larva being able to move vertically in the water column?

options.label: C
options.text: To ride the right currents to find its way to a suitable adult habitat

options.label: D
options.text: To stay in the same water mass

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how do fish larvae typically find their way to a suitable adult habitat?

options.label: A
options.text: By following the same route as their parents

options.label: B
options.text: By using a complex suite of sensory systems, including sound and smell

options.label: D
options.text: By jumping from the water column to the reef below

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the way scientists once thought fish larvae behaved and the way they actually behave?

options.label: A
options.text: Scientists once thought they were more passive, but now we know they are more active in their movements

options.label: B
options.text: Scientists once thought they were more active, but now we know they are less capable of taking their fate in their own fins

options.label: C
options.text: Scientists once thought they were more active in their movements, but now we know they are less capable of navigating their environment

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference between the two views

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why scientists are still unsure about the geographic movements of individual fish larvae?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too small to be tracked

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too fast to be tracked

options.label: C
options.text: Because we don't know which exact environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate to the reefs they will call home

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the bungee system that fish larvae use when finding a suitable coral reef?

options.label: A
options.text: A system where they jump from the water column to the reef below without checking the conditions

options.label: B
options.text: A system where they drop down to check out a reef below and can jump back up if conditions aren't right

options.label: C
options.text: A system where they stay in the water column and wait for the reef to come to them

options.label: D
options.text: A system where they use their fins to propel themselves to the reef

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways in which scientists are still learning about the secret lives of baby fish?

options.label: B
options.text: By tracking their movements using satellite technology

options.label: C
options.text: By studying their larvae in the wild

options.label: D
options.text: By studying their adult behavior in aquariums

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the key aspects of the secret lives of baby fish that remains largely mysterious to us?

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to navigate their environment
